Award.AwardTitle: Renewable Energy Technology Across the Engineering Technology Curriculum

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Educating the next generation of engineers and technicians specialized in renewable energy is of critical importance to our nation's energy security. This project aims to enhance student education in renewable energy and power engineering by: 1) developing and using sun tracking solar power systems as an enabling tool to create innovative teaching materials including demonstrations, hands-on experiments, and course modules; 2) integrating state-of-the-art applications of sustainable energy such as solar, wind, hydro, geothermal, and smart grid into the engineering technology program; and 3) engaging college students in the mentoring of middle and high school students on renewable energy technologies. Curricular enhancements focus on authentic problem solving to engage students in problem-based learning. The progressive approach used in building content knowledge throughout the curriculum prepares graduates with strong backgrounds and the research skills needed to advance the field of renewable energy. The project will reach to community colleges and secondary schools to build a renewable energy education pipeline. The project will provide a model for student recruitment and retention in renewable energy technology. The results of the project will be disseminated in refereed journal publications and conference presentations. The project will contribute to the development of a highly-skilled renewable energy workforce for this nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to the rapid growth of renewable energy technology such as solar and wind power, the nation will have a shortage of skilled power engineers. This project increased the knowledge of renewable energy and power engineering amongst college and pre-college students by 1) developing and using sun tracking solar power systems as an enabling tool to create innovative teaching materials including demonstrations, hands-on experiments, and course modules; 2) integrating state-of-the-art applications of sustainable energy into the engineering technology program; and 3) engaging college students in the mentoring of high school students on renewable energy technologies. 

Intellectual Merits: The project used a progressive approach as participants from different levels – high and middle school students, college students, teachers and faculty engage in collaborative learning about renewable energy. Activities and courses were developed to engage college students and faculty to research renewable energy technology and investigate how these can solve environmental and societal issues. A two-axis sun tracking solar power system was designed, implemented and tested. Enabling teaching materials were developed based on the solar tracker. The teaching materials were used for engineering technology courses, and outreach program for high school students. Students who used the materials learned more than students not using the materials. Also, students using the materials increased their interest in, and confidence in, learning about renewable energy.   

Broader Impact: This project addresses the need for a qualified workforce in the field of renewable energy by directly benefiting 500 students in the Department of Technology. The curricular enhancements focused on authentic problems in renewable energy in ways in which students were engaged in problem-based learning. The progressive, scaffolding approach used in building content knowledge throughout the curriculum prepared graduates with strong content and research skills needed to advance the field of renewable energy. The project attracted students, especially women and under-represented groups, into engineering technology, through outreach activities, open houses, lab tours and seminars. The project has a broad impact on engineering technology education by providing a national model for recruitment and retention of renewable energy technology and improve student learning. The results of the project were disseminated in refereed journal publications and conference presentations, newsletters, and its webpage. 

Publication:

Guo, L., Han, J., and Otieno, A. (2013). Proceedings from American Society of Engineering Education: Design and simulation of a sun tracking solar power system. Atlanta, GA.

Guo, L., Han, J., and Otieno, A. (Fall 2015). Simulation and development of a sun tracking solar power system for electrical engineering technology laboratory. Journal of Engineering Technology, vol. 32, no. 2, pp. 18 – 25.

Guo, L., Bhanoori, S., and Otieno, A. Design of a sun tracking solar power system for laboratory development (under review).
